title: Fivestar4everMVP
author: Fivestar4everMVP
content: I sure should be posting this in the hardware wallet board, but because I want this to reach to as many as possible, most especially, newbies, I decide to post it here. The shot above is a cryptosteel, it can be used to safely and securely store bitcoin wallet seed phrases, as well as passwords, this device is made of 303 and 304 stainless steel, and it is both waterproof, fireproof and shockproof, it is one the best device to own as a bitcoiner and a crypto enthusiast.So, for those of you who are looking for a better way to keep your wallet seed phrases and passwords safe and secure without having to write them on a piece of paper and bury somewhere, of which they could get eaten by termite and other inserts, or use cloud storages to store your seed phrase and passwords, of which the cloud service provider could get hacked, or your account as well could get hacked..So the better option is to own and use this device(cryptosteel), to safely and securely store your seed phrase and wallet passwords.You can check out the device on https://cryptosteel.com/shop/Or find it on ledger on https://shop.ledger.com/products/cryptosteel-capsule-soloFeel free to ask your questions or comment your opinion.

comments.body: Is there any particular reason why you promote this company? I have nothing against them and it's a great product, but there are many other options that allow you to do the same thing. Maybe newbies would like to know all of them? Choose what is convenient for you, for example there are plays that you can etch by scratching your seed. comments.author: Catenaccio
comments.body: Metal Bitcoin Storage ReviewsMetal Bitcoin Seed Storage Stress Test (Round III), with CryptoSteelCryptosteel Capsule reviewQuoteCryptosteel Capsule:Claims to be extremely durable - fireproof up to 1400C/2500F. Shockproof. Waterproof. Stainless.This was pretty easy to assemble other than the final retention pin, though unlike pretty much every other style of device it's fairly annoying to read back due to the orientation and spacing of the tiles. I also noted that it comes with a very large assortment of tiles, which makes it more versatile for potential use cases.Performed admirably - I didn't even have any trouble reopening the capsule by hand.No acid entered the capsule. Even if it had, I doubt any data loss would have occurred.This was an interesting result. I gave it a 50/50 chance of bending and it held up pretty well to several tons of pressure, but eventually gave in a bit to my 20 ton press. The reason the result is interesting is that I didn't anticipate the consequences of bending the tube. Obviously the data inside is still intact, but how are we going to read it? Because the end of the rod is permanently affixed to the screw-on cap, it's now impossible to unscrew the device.I don't have the tools on hand to attempt opening the device, but I expect you'd want to somehow cut through the tube just below where the threads of the cap end. But that's not all! Because there is only a retention clip on the opposite end of the rod, you'd then have to be extremely careful while pulling the rod out of the tube to ensure that the tiles don't fall off, causing data loss. Because this is clearly a suboptimal Schrödinger's cat type of situation with the potential for data loss, I feel the need to deduct a few points.

comments.author: headingnorth
comments.created_time: December 03, 2023, 03:06:55 AMLast edit: December 03, 2023, 03:45:10 AM by headingnorth
comments.body: How does it work exactly? Each disc has one letter on it?Screenshot of Cryptosteel:That seems extremely tedious to manage. So you have to drop the letters in one by one? Seems like a lot could go wrong here:1) You accidentally spelled one or more words wrong while sliding in the discs2) You accidentally assemble one or more words in the wrong order.3) While retrieving your seed phrase, you accidentally allow all the letters to slide out all at once into one big pile, making it impossible to reassemble your words. Which would be extremely easy to do.In either of these scenarios (especially 2 or 3) you are screwed as it would be impossible to put your seed phrase back together, which is the same as losing it.It would make more sense to have each word on one disc, with a number on the disc indicating the order of the word, so in case the discs get mixed up you will always have the correct order of the words. Please tell me I am wrong about how it works? Because judging by the pictures on their website it looks like a not so good idea.

If you mistakenly place a wrong letter or order, then the fault was on you, not the tool. QuoteIt would make more sense to have each word on one disc, with a number on the disc indicating the order of the word, so in case the discs get mixed up you will always have the correct order of the words. Don't worry, @fillippone have created it for you Securing Your Seed Phrase with Washers.There are many tools to save your seed phrase, after all it doesn't mean you need to use all of them, just pick what you think is the best for you.

comments.author: headingnorth
comments.body: The thing that scares me is how easy it would be lose one or more of the 96 little pieces of steel, or even just 24 pieces. That is the inherent problem when working with a large number of physical pieces of something very small.While handling them one or more could roll away somewhere, with or without you being aware of it, and become lost forever. Little objects have a tendency to do that. So you thought you had them all stacked and stored together, but one day when you go to retrieve your seed, you discover that one or more are actually missing.To me it would be a lot safer to use a single or double steel plate with your words stamped on them. Simply punch the letters onto the plate.

comments.author: Z-tight
comments.body: Quote from: Jegileman on December 03, 2023, 10:07:39 AMMy question and what I’m curious about this device is that, if lost, is there a way you can track it back to where it is? Like maybe a sensor in it that can make you to locate it easily if you’ve misplaced it and don’t know exactly where you kept it?Lol, nope, stainless steel is an offline storage that shouldn't have any network connection. Do not lose your seed phrase and if you have good opsec you should always know where you kept it. Take note that you should have more than one backup of your seed phrase and if you ever lose one backup, consider it that the wallet has been compromised and you should sweep your funds immediately into another wallet.
